text:
Hey folks :smiley:

I have an important meeting with an existing client who owns two businesses on Thursday.

They want me to pick up the socials for their second business after my success on the first. However, I need to raise prices and set boundaries. I've not raised prices in 2 years.

I plan to have the 'value' conversation and I'm confident that I generate far more revenue than I cost. But I have a bit of anxiety around walking away if they say no. They are my oldest client and I am passionate about the work.

Any tips, feel free to holler at me. Happy to take calls.

elements.text:

I plan to have the 'value' conversation and I'm confident that I generate far more revenue than I cost. But I have a bit of anxiety around walking away if they say no. They are my oldest client and I am passionate about the work.

Any tips, feel free to holler at me. Happy to take calls.

text: you've got this. clients who respect your work understand that quality will cost them more, and a lot changes in 2 years for them too -- they might have more budget wiggle room

text:
<@U01FUP6AMEZ> - Thanks for being brave enough to say something. I similarly found this “opportunity” to be exploitative of human talent and labor. I also don’t personally fault the poster but rather ClassPass’s senior leadership, founders, board, and VCs.

In my experience in my Silicon Valley circles, I’ve seen many class action lawsuits unfold in response to companies engaging in these exploitative and abusive practices (let’s call it what it is). 

I give everyone the benefit of the doubt. “Corporate America” has roots in slavery, and freelancers don’t have labor rights like w-2 employees. In my experience, a lot of American companies “don’t see it” and end up implementing policies like this, that ultimately get them in trouble for exploiting “labor.” People in corporate leadership don’t recognize their own bullying. 

I have been in Callahan’s exact role before, being part of a big company engaging in practices that took advantage of freelancers. I made the choice to approach my bosses and board with the issue. I was “scolded” (I was 22) and banned from working with our company lawyers. Six months later, we got sued.

I was then promoted 2X, my salary was doubled, and I received access to my own team of lawyers (2) to lead, operationalize, and execute my ideas. I had a lot of respect at the company for being willing to speak up and bring “difficult” topics to my leadership team’s attention — to show them a bigger picture.

So there’s a silver lining to these discussions in terms of building pathways to new plateaus of leadership. 

I appreciate that Jimmy has created a space for all of us to have these important conversations. Superpath is invaluable for our industry. I am constantly in awe of Jimmy’s decision-making and think our industry is better because of everything he’s building.

elements.text:

In my experience, a lot of American companies “don’t see it” and end up implementing policies like this, that ultimately get them in trouble for exploiting “labor.” People in corporate leadership don’t recognize their own bullying. 

I have been in Callahan’s exact role before, being part of a big company engaging in practices that took advantage of freelancers. I made the choice to approach my bosses and board with the issue. I was “scolded” (I was 22) and banned from working with our company lawyers. Six months later, we got sued.

I was then promoted 2X, my salary was doubled, and I received access to my own team of lawyers (2) to lead, operationalize, and execute my ideas. I had a lot of respect at the company for being willing to speak up and bring “difficult” topics to my leadership team’s attention — to show them a bigger picture.

So there’s a silver lining to these discussions in terms of building pathways to new plateaus of leadership. 

I appreciate that Jimmy has created a space for all of us to have these important conversations. Superpath is invaluable for our industry. I am constantly in awe of Jimmy’s decision-making and think our industry is better because of everything he’s building.

text:
<@UL9SA4C3T> I'm interested to hear how you approached your scenario. I certainly wasn't scolded or banned from talking to anyone when I brought up that people should be paid, but more so was told to work with what I got. How did you handle resourcing when you were in my situation? (Genuinely looking to hear your thoughts. :slightly_smiling_face: )

Additionally, I'd like to know the thoughts from everyone in this thread on guest posting. I know many people utilize SME's or guest bloggers to write without compensation, but the company reaps the majority of the benefit and seems to fall within a gray area. Where does that fall within exploitation?

Where does that fall within exploitation?
